snippet: The fight for Amerli appeared to mark the first time American warplanes and militias backed by Iran were working with a common purpose on the battlefield against militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
abstract: American warplanes and Iran-backed militias, though not coordinating efforts, work with common goal on battlefields of northern Iraq to punch through defenses of Islamic State; should such military actions continue, they could signal dramatic shift for the United States and Iran, which have long vied for control in Iraq, and could align interest of Americans with longtime sworn enemies in Shiite militias.

byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and AZAM AHMED
byline.contributor: Tim Arango reported from Baghdad, and Azam Ahmed from Qaryat Salam, Iraq. Reporting was contributed by Ali Hamza and Omar al-Jawoshy from Baghdad; an employee of The New York Times from Sulaiman Bek, Iraq; and Helene Cooper from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The fight for Amerli appeared to mark the first time American warplanes and militias backed by Iran were working with a common purpose on the battlefield against militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

headline.main: U.S. and Iran Unlikely Allies in Iraq Battle
headline.print_headline: U.S. and Iran Unlikely Allies in Iraq Battle
